column5: Business Rule

column6: The number of bags can only be changed if the previous number of bags is known, which is obtained by scanning the ticket. This creates a data dependency that dictates the order of the activities.

column4: The ticket must be scanned to retrieve the passenger's information before any changes can be made, reflecting a commonly accepted procedure in the airline industry.
The ticket must be scanned first to retrieve the passenger's information, which is necessary for validating the documents. This reflects a standard procedure commonly accepted in the industry.

The process description indicates that the airline's employees typically scan the ticket first before weighing the luggage, as it allows for gathering necessary passenger information and enhances operational efficiency.

column5: The airline has established a rule that requires the ticket to be scanned first to determine its validity before any cancellation can occur.
The airline wants the check-in (which includes scanning the ticket) to be completed before processing any payment, which is a rule established by the airline.
The airline requires the ticket to be scanned before the check-in of luggage to ensure all necessary passenger information is obtained.
The airline has established a rule that check-in (which includes scanning the ticket) must be completed before the luggage can be loaded onto the aircraft.

column4: The process indicates that passenger information is needed to handle change requests, and it is common practice to have this information before making changes.

column5: The airline has established a procedure where changes to the number of bags can be handled before validating the documents, reflecting a rule under their jurisdiction.

column4: The process description indicates that the airline staff typically handle changes to the number of bags before weighing the baggage to ensure the correct number is processed.

column5: The process description indicates that changes to the number of bags can be made before the check-in is finalized, reflecting the airline's internal rules regarding handling passenger requests.
The airline has established a rule that requires any changes to the number of bags to be handled before processing payment.
The airline has established a rule that check-in must occur only after any changes to the number of bags have been handled.
The airline has established a specific process that requires the number of bags to be confirmed and any changes to be made before the luggage is loaded onto the aircraft.

column4: The process description indicates that it is a standard procedure among the staff to handle change requests based on passenger information before validating documents.

The process description indicates that airline staff typically handle passenger requests for changes (like changing seats) before moving on to weighing the baggage, reflecting a standard procedure accepted by the staff.
It is standard procedure to address any changes, such as seat changes, before finalizing the check-in process to ensure all passenger requests are accommodated.

column5: The airline has established a specific process where changes to a passenger's seat must be handled before any payment is processed, reflecting a rule under the airline's jurisdiction.

column4: The process indicates that handling change requests, such as changing a seat, is done before the check-in of luggage, reflecting an accepted procedure within the organization to enhance efficiency.

column5: The airline has established a specific process that requires the change of seat to be completed before the luggage is loaded.
The organization has established a rule that requires document validation to occur before any further actions, including weighing the baggage.
The organization has established a rule that requires the validation of documents before any cancellation can occur.
The airline has established a rule that requires the validity of documents to be confirmed before processing any payment, as invalid documents would cancel the check-in process.
The airline has established a rule that requires document validation prior to check-in, as indicated by the statement that invalid documents can cancel the whole process.
The airline has established a rule that requires the validity of documents to be checked before proceeding with the loading of luggage.

The process description indicates that weighing the baggage is an important step to ensure that the luggage is within safe limits for manual handling and is necessary before proceeding with the check-in process.
The airline requires baggage to be weighed before processing payment for overweight luggage, which is a rule established by the airline.
The airline enforces that check-in can only occur after weighing the luggage to ensure it is within safe limits and to account for weight in the takeoff calculation.
The airline has a specific requirement that luggage must be weighed before it can be loaded onto the aircraft to ensure safety and compliance with operational protocols.
The airline's operational procedures dictate that payment processing should not occur if the check-in is canceled due to invalid tickets or passports.
The airline has established a rule that requires the cancellation of the check-in to occur before any further activities, such as checking in the luggage.
The airline has established a rule that requires the cancellation of the check-in to occur before any loading of luggage can take place.
The airline wants the check-in to be done only after the payment has been processed, indicating an internal policy.
The airline has established a rule that requires payment to be processed before the luggage is loaded onto the aircraft.
The airline has established a specific requirement that check-in must be completed before the luggage can be loaded onto the aircraft.
